review_title: It’s a great place to work - however….
pros: Great culture, good benefits, supportive and appreciative management.
cons: Difficult to move up. As someone who has wanted to work at TWDC for years, I joined as a FSW to gain some brand and culture experience. I realized that working there as a corporate employee would be amazing, and started to ask my management team for meetings with higher level managers to get an idea of what I needed to do or who I needed to talk with. I was told I needed to do this while on the clock. I worked nights and weekends, usual time off for those people I needed to meet with. So, that was a barrier. Meanwhile, people left and right who have been there for well over 7-10 years are getting promoted. Happy for them, of course, but I wasn’t ready to invest that much time in the parks to get to a corporate role with 13 years of experience, 7 of which were IN a corporate role. Not to mention, I have two master degrees that are appropriate for several positions. Long story short, unless you know someone or have been there for a while, don’t expect to be moved up or hired to the corporate level. Go on LinkedIn and see for yourself - internal promotes announce their promotion all the time. Also, the one time I messaged a recruiter for advice, she responded (in essence) with “this is what I’m looking for in this role. If you have the experience, apply.” And nothing else regarding the rest of my email. Isn’t a recruiters job to find candidates? You would think she could have referred me to someone or another recruiter hiring for roles with my qualifications and experience.

review_title: The Happiest Place on Earth For Some
job_title: Bus Operator in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros:
Guest interaction is top notch, the people are fun and welcoming and the company provides ALL your training whether you come in with a CDL or not, which is a huge plus.

Big Pluses: You can sit down when everyone else is required to stand, you are inside and dry when it is raining and you get a nice air conditioned bus when it's 100 degrees out
cons:
The company plans for call outs so they schedule way more drivers than are needed. As a result it is not uncommon to sit around for hours or even your whole shift with nothing to do.

The Transportation system runs on an automated dispatch system, which is incorrectly timed. The result is that drivers will regularly be early for scheduled runs and will not be able to have access to their dispatched slot, since it will be filled with another bus waiting to leave.

Guests can be abusive and aggressive especially when it is hot, raining, or they are running late.

review_title: Love my team but frustrated with post-pandemic return to the office
job_title: Category Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: My manager and team are the best. I feel supported in my role and my work is emotionally rewarding. I work with a relatively small group of stakeholders, some of whom are truly thought leaders in their area of expertise. There used to be great benefits if you lived near a Park (Orlando, Anaheim), but those aren't available currently.
cons:
Return to work in person is being handled with a very old-school approach. It feels like leadership learned nothing from the last 16+ months. 
Leadership clearly does not care about the preferences of their workforce. I expect many resignations in the Fall/Winter due to their return policy.
Main issues with their approach:
- No survey of employees or input asked for before rolling out the return plan
- Strong focus on how collaboration and free exchange of ideas happens best in person (old-school)
- One-size fits all approach of a minimum of 3 days per week in person "to begin," implying that requirement will increase
- No differentiation between the types of roles that have been working from home successfully since March 2020
Other issues: Park access benefits have been revoked since the pandemic with no replacement to our compensation package, leadership can be very top-down in general with little regard for the thoughts of their teams, benefits (medical, 401k, etc) are below market average, pay is below market average, heavy reliance on brand to recruit & retain instead of compensation

job_title: Infrastructure Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
Though Disney+ is a large platform, Disney Streaming is a technically developing sector of Disney, and therefore there is much opportunity to make impactful changes to the sector.

Disney Streaming begs for open technical discussion and intellectual conversation, which enables both itself, its systems, and its employees to be tempered.
cons:
Sometimes there is TOO little handholding, which for example can lead to issues like it being totally up to the employee to have yearly reviews with their manager. That is not to say it is difficult to have such conversations, but if an employee does want a raise, they should be prepared to leverage another offer.

Although this con exists, it is a consequence of the incredible freedom that the company offers, and overall I am personally willing to accept the con for the pros.

pros: They finally raised salaries to almost the industry average.
cons:
Salary is still low compared to not only the industry but the job requirements and demands across multiple job titles and departments.

With the raise almost average many benefits previously utilized were slashed for cheaper options.

Little to no room from growth in the company particularly with the pandemic in mind.

High turnover due to extensive demands well beyond the accompanying salary, slashed benefits, and further encroachment into employees work-life balance. Industry standard best practices are virtually no longer in place in order to VP’s and executive level leadership trying to prove they are “innovative” with their lackluster (for a better word) ideas. While this may get them the gold star on fridge it comes at the expense of the employees doing their jobs as effectively as they could.

The high turnover has contributed to further extensive demands on employees who remain, and is pushing additional employees to decide to opt out. Moral is not ideal to put it kindly across the board.

job_title: Software Engineer I in Glendale, CA
pros:
Free park admission, company notoriety, large audience.

Depending on the team, flexibility for remote and hybrid work.
cons:
Low wages across the board, lack of promotions, poor retainment incentives. As a developer, don’t expect the highest engineering standards. Documentation is scarce and legacy knowledge is constantly lost by high turnover.

Everyone is leaving because the market is extremely competitive and Disney refuses to change its policy of paying 15% under market value. That’s right— wages are kept from candidates because that’s how low they are. Their old policy of “you just really have to like Disney to work here” is failing them, and lo and behold, nobody wants to work here.

There’s an old adage here, stated by every one of the many teams I’ve been on: “If you want to get promoted, you have to leave and come back.” Opportunities for advancement here are not a priority, and no one is going to come back once they’ve experienced decent pay elsewhere.

Tech employees (specifically programmers) are offered a long-term incentive package in the form of restricted stock units, which is taxed as imputed income and not even close to a valid supplement for a fair salary.

Park admission used to be the huge selling point for a corporate gig here, but the pandemic has changed that and getting into a park requires advanced planning/scheduling and a pretty competitive booking calendar. It’s hardly worth it anymore.

They say Disney is a good starting point for your career elsewhere. That seems to be true— name recognition may work to get you a nice job where you actually want to work, and until Disney updates its compensation policies, it will continue to be the main draw.

pros:
To be honest, I’m really only writing this to use Glassdoor to look for other jobs, but:

* The benefits are actually good.

* I really can’t stress enough that the cast members really make it worth it.
cons:
* Management. Oh yes. The amount of corporate backstabbing is sickening. Favoritism is the #1 thing around here. Some parks are worse than others.

* Guests. 90% of you guys are alright. The 10% are incredibly rude, selfish, and entitled degenerates that ruin the enjoyment of the other 90%.

* The verbal abuse that you will receive on an almost daily basis is pretty much guaranteed. Will managers back you up? Maybe. Maybe not.

* Unions. We’re unionized for the most part (and if you’re not you’re in for a worse time); but this is an at-will state. It’s effectively worthless. Especially since your senior staff in the unions work for the company!

* as above: you’d better LOVE working here because if you plan on living in the general area you’d better either work super-long hours (if your department allows for it) or you have secondary income like pension or a second job or something. The pay is appalling especially for the job you’re going to do.

Politics between my boss and skip level boss made life pretty difficult, my boss thought the skip level boss was naive and doesn't know what he is asking and has no idea the amount of work we do. My team was asked to write a business case for a technical upgrade and they worked on it for 2+ years and ultimately leadership approved it because they were running out of time. Who in the world requires a business case for technical upgrade ? At one time I submitted a ticket for approval and my boss literally told me that she is not sitting there for me to give her work, she was the one who created the approval process and yet saying those things triggered me to leave the company.

review_title: Itinerary Planner at the Tampa DRC (Disney Reservation Center)
pros:
They try to keep the Disney magic even in the office. 
You have a direct supervisor to build your relationship with. 
Disney park perks such as admission and discounts. 
Opportunity to earn extras with overtime hours worked.
cons:
Required OT all of the time = Overworked. 
Never ending phone calls requiring precision to what topics to touch on, how much the guest must sign up for, speed of phone call regardless of customer needs, and of course, all of the appropriate Disney language. This is incredibly stressful when doing it for 2 hours straight at a time before getting a small break. In addition, if you don't make enough points in sales, they will make you a guest (aka fired). The number of points one must meet is always changing so that there will always be people in the lowest 3% living in fear of losing their jobs no matter how magical they are.

review_title: Do not expect any career development, progression, or company culture during your time.
pros:
Good Benefits.
Strong media brands to lean into.
Disney parks pass - if you're a fan.
Hire great people but retention is poor due to career development below leadership.
cons:
Do not expect any progression within the company even with high performance.
Personal development and training are never looked at.
Department leaders do not communicate to their teams and disregard any feedback from anyone below them. 
No team culture. You're made to feel like it's a privilege to work for Disney, so the company or team leaders will make no effort to make it a great place to work. 
Too many unclear company objectives. If you and your team do not align with those objectives, your work feels worthless.
Not a huge amount of value outside of the US for sales clients, outside of partnering with strong media brands.

job_title: Entertainment Costuming Hostess in Riverside, CA
pros: The employee discounts were great. You would get seasonal coupons to use in park to get even better discounts. The employee store was also one of my favorite perks. Property control had a range of basic items like old dishes/robes from the hotel to old Christmas decorations or furniture from around the resort. Of course you had a set of sign ins you could use and you would get tickets after every peak season, I ended up never using them due to not wanting to go into the park after work.
cons:
The scheduling can be very crazy depending on which department you work for and how high your seniority is. I would go from a normal 10-18:30 shift to a 22:00-6:30 and back again throughout the week. Once I was there for a few years it was easier to get control over my schedule, but you will for sure be working holidays and weekends. 
Parking was another big issue. My department was relocated to a lot that took 15-50 min to walk to after your shift (depending on where you were working in the park, and if a parade was going). It took time to park and get to your location all of which you weren't getting paid for.

review_title: It’s Disney, but unprofessional middle/upper management, unethical hiring practices
pros: Disney content is exciting and fun to work on interesting content/operations
cons:
They do not promote internally in the finance organization and your contributions are made to feel insignificant. Lateral movement is encouraged but not vertical movement, they will gladly hire externally instead of promote internally. Additionally talent acquisition completely ignores status requests for internal interviews.  After multiple follow ups and cc’ing HR, you finally get a response with no actual feedback. Terrible way to treat internal employees.

Reorgs happen all the time and constant upper management turnover.

Regarding hiring practices, candidates I interviewed that were qualified for the job were turned down by upper management because “they were not diverse enough”. This is likely illegal in some form or at least unethical, and in a finance/accounting role, diversity should not apply in qualifications

review_title: Amazing company  but poor career progression
job_title: Human Resources Professional in London, England
pros:
- Working for Disney is like a dream come true for some. it really does feel like a magical place to work when things are good
- Great company culture for the most part with a lot of resources and awareness shared on mental health and wellbeing (general wellbeing of employees in reality is questionable as per my cons comments)
- HR staff genuinely care and do their best to support clients/ employees in the business 
- Inhouse cinema is pretty cool 
- Amazing BERG participation opportunities available for those who want to get involved in extra things beyond their day-to-day role 
- Benefits are quite good (parks pass or disneyplus subscription). Summertime and wellbeing hours are also nice when they can be used. 
- People managers are generally quite competent and good at leading others. If they are not good they tend to be performance managed quite effectively.
cons:
- Salaries aren't London weighted which is unusual seeing as they have a dedicated comp team 
- annual merit review is minimal even if you work your guts out and have outstanding feedback. The increase is marginal 
- headcount process is extremely rigid which makes it difficult for allow growth in org structures. Apply that to waiting for months for your own promotion (having been told you deserve it) and you can see why people get fed up and leave... 
- North America seem to convolute processes and make things unnecessarily inefficient and hierarchical. More autonomy should be given to local/regional HR teams instead of needing every single thing scrutinised by North America powers that be 
- Generally no one works their core hours. Workload is extremely high and it is expected of you to start early and work late in order to stay on top of things, regardless of your level
- It's almost impossible to negotiate change in a company as big as Disney. I tried several times in my first few months but gave up and learned to just keep my head down and do what I'm told.
- Poor internal recruitment process with no consistency on how this is managed

pros: Working in Security at Disney World is very different from other lines of business. You aren’t tied to one theme park or resort, in fact you can work at all of them! As a security office coordinator (SOC) you can still pick up front-line (security host) shifts. Some locations or shifts may require specialized training (such as Bike Training).
cons: Management differs at each location. Some locations have great and supportive managers who are very knowledgeable, sometime you run into managers who are insufferable with little knowledge of policy and procedures. SOCs do a lot of work behind the scenes and often don’t get enough recognition or respect for everything they do.

pros: Discounts for many places, including phone bills, etc. That's about it.
cons:
There is so much hierarchy and political bullsh*t. You need authorizations to do every piece of your job.

Management sucks; they don't care about their employees - all employees are treated as line items. Personally, I was treated as a commodity. They actively gaslight their employees - I would suggest my workflow, which they would beat to death saying it is wrong, only to circle back 1-2 days later to tell you to do what you suggested. I fell into a specific area of expertise prior to TWDC where I was harassed and mistreated by both my client and management, and because my client was one of the largest retailer accounts, management prioritized back-bending to them regardless of the mountains of emails and other proof I had. And don't even get me started on human resources. Rather than helping you or hearing out your issues, they force you to work with an "outside" employee relations department who will do any and everything to protect their management.

At best, you will get paid more than other studios in the industry. But you will be expected to work all hours of the day (I used to get emails at 12, 1, sometimes 2am from colleagues) and management will not care if you are doing OK.

pros: The people that you work with on a daily basis are the best part of working for Disney. The pay was good for the location and the benefits were good, but they became quite expensive over the years.
cons: Things got progressively worse over my 15+ years with Disney. They reduced our pensions and continued to raise our portion of the health benefits. They chose to furlough me (a 15+ year employee) and keep on my coworker that had less than 1 year with the company. During the furlough period, I received 0 communication from the company. Not even an email saying "hey, we're thinking about you and know that this is a difficult time". Now, Disney is forcing thousands of CA Cast Members to relocate to FL and they're forcing Cast Members to get vaccinated. This is not the same Disney culture that attracted me to the company when I joined.

pros:
You will meet some of the most wonderful people you have ever met and you will create lifelong friendships. 
Merchandise as well as the food & beverage discounts are a nice perk. The original best perk used to be bringing friends and family into the parks with you.
Many areas offer employment to a diverse range of people from all cultural backgrounds as well as those with disabilities, as long as the area is able to accommodate. For example, someone who is wheelchair bound wouldn't be offered a position where they have to climb ladders
cons:
Staff is under-paid and overworked. Work life balance does not exist. I experienced peers getting reprimanded for things they shouldn't be reprimanded for. Now with the park reservation system, cast members essentially cannot enter the parks let alone bring family and friends along.
Executives care more about themselves than about the frontline workers. If that was not the case, they would not have accepted their full pay AND bonuses back prior to cast members coming back to work. The executives got their pay and bonuses back at the cost of 30,000+ cast members' jobs.
You cannot move up if you do not know people but in order to know people, you have to have a work life balance to meet with them. Many areas are overworked so you get off the clock extremely tired.
All company values went out the window. The company used to preach that they cared for the employees but the true colors came to light thanks to covid.

pros: I get a regular paycheck.
cons: Disney is a social justice political action organization that just happens to own theme parks, television channels, and movie studios. They make no secret to employees that they want to use their products to advance very Left-wing social views in society – the same way they force them down their employees throats on a near-daily basis. They have all but explicitly stated that whites, especially white males, will be discriminated against in hiring and promotions going forward in multiple company town halls. Employees are subjected to a seemingly endless barrage of town halls and seminars on “anti-racism” (which is really proactive racism against whites), bias, and identity politics, and even high-ranking executives are too afraid to speak up for fear of reprisals. The atmosphere of political correctness is suffocating. And while our benefits keep being cut (I now have an HMO with a deductible), the company keeps wasting big money on repetitive workshops with speakers peddling the same race grievance hustle.
